Waterfront revitalization in post-industrial port cities of North America: a cultural approach
Introduction: toward a cultural theory of waterfront revitalization
Waterfront revitalization is a seemingly ubiquitous process in urban North America, and increasingly common in Europe and Australasia as well. This process normally entails the displacement of formerly waterfront industrial and commercial zones by new mixed-used office and residential development, and associated upscale retail services, festival marketplaces, leisure areas and public amenities. While in North America this pattern is most visible in the showpiece seaport cities like Boston, Baltimore, Toronto, Seattle, Vancouver, and San Francisco, these development strategies are evident in cities of all sizes, at all levels in the urban hierarchy, and located on inland waterways as well as on the sea. In the United States alone, fully “Seventy percent of the 415 cities...with a population over 50,000...are located on the edge of a river, lake, bay, or ocean” (Heritage Conservation and Recreation Service 1980: 1 ), and as Hoyle notes, “Virtually every north American city possessed of an urban waterfront. . . has taken some steps towards the rediscovery and redevelopment of the [port-city or waterfront] interface zone” (Hoyle 1988: 15).
If its ubiquity is one striking feature of waterfront revitalization in North America, another is its broadly uniform character from place to place: development seems to take broadly the same physical shape, and displays the same general cultural themes, whatever the location. How is this uniformity to be accounted for? While common design models and state policies no doubt play a role, here I would like to propose a broader, more holistic cultural model
* R. Timothy Sieber is a associate Professor of Anthropology at the University of Massachusetts al Boston, USA. During winter and spring 1998 he will be affiliated with the Departamento de Ciências Humanas e Sociais at the Universidade Aberta de Lisboa, as a Senior Fulbright Scholar and Cientista Convidado under JNICT’s PRAXIS XXI program.
to explain these developments. This model takes into account current urban economic restructuring, the emergence of new, mostly elite urban newcomer groups, and creation by these groups of new cultural frameworks for understanding and shaping the changing city. The elements of the argument are as follows.
The ubiquity and much of the uniformity in appearance of waterfront revitalization are conditioned by a common set of underlying structural changes that have encompassed the North American economy in the late 20th century, as a consequence of global economic integration, and that are transforming the economic function of a large and particular set of its cities in a post-industrial direction. This post-industrial transition has resulted in the ascendancy of service and information industries in urban economies, and the increasing colonization of downtown and waterfront districts by new urban professionals; by tourists, including business travelers; and by suburban visitors. Standard redevelopment models appear, and enjoy sustained marketability in most cases, because they address the needs, values, and aspirations of these new populations - few of whom are long-term urban residents - who increasingly populate the downtown areas.
New visions of the meaning of the city, and of its fundamental relations to nature, history, and work, are represented in the broad themes of redevelopment planning, programming and marketing that are visible on urban waterfronts. These new visions not only articulate the sensibilities of the city’s new elite residents and visitors, but are becoming dominant in the broader public culture of the late 20th century post-industrial city. They increasingly shape the broader set of representations the city makes of itself, that it projects both internally and externally, and that it uses to guide its planning for further development. Analysis of these themes in waterfront redevelopment allows, in Fox’s terms, an understanding of “how the ideological motifs of the society are imbedded in the culture of its cities, and...how the urban locale projects self-generated beliefs onto its environs” (Fox 1977: 17-18).
My remarks will concern primarily North American, and particularly United States, port cities. In later sections, I attempt to demarcate more precisely the particular historical and economic features that define the broad class of postindustrial cities referred to here, and will address international dimensions. Among my example cities in the discussion to follow, I will draw frequently on Boston, where I have been engaged in long-term field research on waterfront development for a decade. Information from other North American cities comes chiefly from secondary sources, especially the extensive publications of The Waterfront Center, in Washington, D. C. (Breen and Rigby 1987b, 1988) and their quarterly publication, Waterfront World, which regularly reviews waterfront developments on the continent.
Structural conditions promoting waterfront revitalization
Three basic structural factors provide essential conditions for the emergence of waterfront revitalization in port cities. Indeed, in the sites where these structural conditions are more fully met, waterfront revitalization has taken its most dramatic forms. These are: (1) obsolescence and change in the technology of transportation and cargo-handling, (2) deindustrialization, and (3) corporatization of the city.
(1)	Technological Obsolescence in Transportation and Cargo-Handling. A number of developments in the mid 20th century have rendered most sea-and river-port cities, and their port facilities, obsolete as centers for water-borne commerce, transportation, and cargo-handling. In passenger transportation, air transport has displaced water as the major form of public inter-city and transoceanic travel, obviating the need for passenger liner terminals in downtown waterfronts. Post-World War II containerization of most shipping cargoes has also required centralized, mostly mechanized handling, and large port transfer areas accessible to trucks and railroads. Because of the need for these larger, more concentrated spaces for container storage and handling, most port facilities have thus been migrating “downstream” for several decades, away from central city waterfronts, to less congested areas with deeper water, also technological necessity in order to accommodate today’s larger-sized freighter and tanker ships (Riley and Shurmer-Smith 1988).
In these newer container terminals, a single crane can unload in an afternoon the tonnage that 30 years ago required a week of 50 strong men. Not only are labor demands reduced through the new technology, but much less shoreline is required for cargo transfers and storage. In most major seaports, miles of downtown finger piers and warehouses have thus been rendered obsolete, decaying, and open for redevelopment.
(2)	Deindustrialization. Deindustrialization of inner-city areas has been a long process occurring in various regions of the US since World War I. Manufacturing was decentralized, first, from inner-city areas to outer, suburban locations, and from older urban regions, particularly the northeast and uppermidwest, to newly developing sun-belt areas. These processes accelerated especially after World War II. In the 1980’s, manufacturing activity has taken an even more precipitous decline, as multinational corporations have decentralized operations further from US cities and suburban areas to overseas locations (Bluestone and Harrison 1982), as part of global economic restructuring.
Significant port cities tend to be sites of industry, and their Post World War II declines in manufacturing activities have been sharp. “Between 1953 and 1980, employment in manufacturing and construction industries as a share of total private sector employment dropped from 40 to 23% in New York City, 50 to 27% in Philadelphia, and 32 to 17% in Boston (Dillman and Beck 1986:
46). In Boston, recent declines have been even more severe: between 1969 and 1988, manufacturing employment in the city declined a full 50% (Economic Development Industrial Corporation 1989). In traditionally industrial Pittsburgh, manufacturing jobs have recently dropped from half to 18% of the local total (Knack 1985).
Much of the deactivated manufacturing and other industrial facilities in port cities have been at waterfront locations, including maritime-related facilities such as shipyards, but also other industries like steel and automobiles, heavily dependent upon water transport of raw materials. Shipbuilding, a heavy industry closely associated with ports, has undergone an almost total collapse in the US. These losses in manufacturing jobs, together with loss of traditional cargohandling jobs on the piers, have undercut the economic base of many workingclass inner-city waterfront communities, and promoted displacement of residents. Industrial closings have opened up many additional parcels of commercial and industrial waterfront land for redevelopment, but made portside working-class neighborhoods vulnerable to gentrification.
(3) Corporatization. A corollary economic development to deindustrialization is the shift in the base of central city economies to the corporate, information, and service sectors. Activities such as banking and finance, business and professional services, corporate headquarters, real estate development, tourism, health care, education, and government come to dominate in the urban economy, transforrping it in a fundamentally new direction. Urban observers from a wide variety of disciplines have commented on this transformation and the new kind of city that is emerging. Plotnicov has referred to the new city type aff the “city of the corporate skyscrapers” (1987), Castells has called it the “Informational City” (1985), Gordon (1978) the “Corporate City,” and Mollenkopf (1983) and others, the “Post-industrial City.” Increasingly, as Alvin Wolfe noted a decade ago, the most prominent of these cities function as service centers for international capital, and sites for the managerial coordination of multi-national enterprise (Wolfe 1980).
As manufacturing and commerce decline, giant new organizations — representing the private, public and non-profit sectors — expand and occupy increasingly proliferating office towers in the central cities (Mollenkopf 1983). The downtown gentrification and “revitalization” taking place in these cities, much of it centered on their waterfronts, can be seen as a response to the consumption and leisure needs of the multitudes of urban professionals who staff these new bureaucracies (Plotnicov 1987, 1990; Sieber 1987, 1989). Not only have newly developed waterfront areas spawned almost exclusively luxury housing to accommodate the professional newcomers, but retail and other available services have been generally upscale. Waterfronts everywhere have become transformed from places associated with working class people and manual work to the province of the newly arrived bourgeois urban professionals.
Port Cities and Post-Industrial Transitions. Established port cities, it appears, are especially likely to experience these post-industrial economic transitions. John H. Mollenkopf (1983) has pointed out that the most likely sites for post-industrial urban transformations in general are cities with a balanced mix of industry, services, and commerce in their economies, usually the legacy of their long and diverse economic histories. These cities, he writes, usually have significant early industrial histories, spanning the late 19th and early 20th centuries, with manufacturing beginning its decline often prior to World War II. They are also cities that have developed corporate and service economies coincident with industrial decline, quite often because they were important commercial centers before ever becoming industrial in the mid to late 19th century (Mollenkopf 1983: 40-41). Although Mollenkopf is mainly interested in growth of Central Business Districts and does not specifically address port cities or waterfront revitalization, his characterization applies quite well, of course, to most sea- and river-ports, including Boston, New York, New Orleans, Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, Seattle, and San Francisco, all of which have long histories as centers of mercantile commerce and administration prior to industrialization. Newer, post World War II sunbell cities, from the outset predominantly service-oriented and post-industrial, of course, have little industrial legacy to redevelop and are thus not likely sites for waterfront revitalization. A third category of cities, that have been more recent |post-World War III industrial centers, but that have never been major administrative or service nodes - Youngstown, Ohio and Gary, Indiana are the ones mentioned by Mollenkopf (1983: 41) - also are not likely sites for waterfront revitalization, perhaps because they do not have the critical global links or the market of urban professionals to promote and support redevelopment.
Cultural Elements in the Redevelopment Programs of Revitalizing Port Cities.
The post-industrial transformations affecting so many cities in the advanced capitalist world constitute major changes in living and working patterns for many urbanites. For the poor and working-class, decline in living standards, marginalization, and displacement have often been the end results of deindustrialization and gentrification (Bluestone and Harrison 1982). The new, usually migrant urban professionals, on the other hand, enter the cities on a more optimistic note, but devoid of roots, community ties, and connection with local traditions.
Most of the emerging cultural themes evident in the public culture of newly revitalized waterfronts speak to these newcomers’ needs for familiar frameworks for understanding their identity as urbanites, and their newfound connections to local places and traditions. Suburban visitors and tourists to the city face similar needs for connection to place and traditions. Programming in
waterfront revitalization is usually effective in responding to these newcomers’ sensibilities and values, because it is planned and managed by urban professionals themselves, in the planning, real estate development, governmental, and nonprofit educational sectors (Sieber 1989). They create, as well as consume, the newly emerging urban environments.
A particularly salient theme is the search for authentic experiences in the midst of a social environment widely understood to be new, artificial, and constantly changing (Handler 1986; MacCannell 1989). As Handler has noted, “modern individualistic culture” makes it increasingly difficult for people ever to complete or perfect themselves as individuals (1987: 339). Ultimately, they are driven to seek completion through establishing connections to external domains defined as real, pure, or true. Programming in waterfront revitalization, in fact, centers on creating contexts and opportunities for people to establish such connections. These connections also serve to fix them in time and space in the newly structured city in which they find themselves. Typically, revitalization programming and images are designed to connect people with three domains: unspoiled nature, to an unchanging past, and to spontaneous fun and enjoyment. These connections are achieved through three different complexes of redevelopment ideology and practice: (1) environmentalism, (2) history and heritage, and (3) tourism and public celebration, respectively.
(1) Environmentalism. There is a general growth in “ecological consciousness” regarding water evident in most redeveloping waterfront cities, as the public, private, and especially non-profit sectors work to enhance and promote their waterways as “natural resources.” Often, as in the case of Pittsburgh’s rivers, this involves recreational development of shorelines and waters (Mueller 1989; Erkel 1989). Usually, also, environmental cleansing and enhanced pollution control precede or accompany waterfront revitalization. Water pollution control facilities, in fact, have recently displaced highways as the country’s chief public infrastructural investment (Breen and Rigby 1987a). In Boston, tor example, a six billion dollar harbor clean-up effort accompanies current waterfront development efforts. Such clean-up efforts are necessary to rehabilitate polluted urban waterways for new recreational use, parkland, and as clean and scenic backdrop for office and residential construction. In general, as marine industry, commerce, and trades decline, aesthetic and public health considerations become more prominent in public programs and views regarding the water (Sieber 1993).
New parklands and other leisure areas are designed to provide access, for the most part passive visual access, to the water itself. Recreational activities programmed for are usually either the passive or low-technology types more customary to the middle class: bicycling, jogging, walking, picnicking, and sailboating. More profane, mass-oriented, leisure accompaniments — such as cars, power boats, amplified sound, alcohol — are usually not accommodated (Sieber 1989). The move to restore “natural” conditions in order to satisfy
bourgeois tastes is not only limited to the international rural tourist sites, but applies to central cities in the developed world as well. In both types of settings, development can actually lead to displacement of long-standing active uses of the environment, including recreational ones, by local indigenous or working-class populations (Sieber 1989).
As those who visit, work, or live on the waterfront more and more lack “working” knowledge of the urban coastline and waterfront, they require interpreters to explain these environments to them. Waterfront developments often provide a plethora structured educational contexts that mediate the public’s relationship to the environment. Aquariums and other water-related museums, for example, are quite often designed as the centerpieces of waterfront projects. The New England Aquarium, for example, was planned in 1962 as one of the first steps in redevelopment of Boston’s downtown waterfront (Sheehan 1984: 40-41), and other cities - most notably Baltimore - have followed this model. Among the North American cities presently planning new aquaria as part of redevelopment efforts are Denver, Toronto, New Orleans, Boston, Chattanooga, and Montreal.
Aquaria and water-related museums typically interpret water-related environments for the public through controlled, simulated reproductions of natural settings. Recreated environments always include the local, but in the “world cities” that tend to be developing the new aquaria, there is also an appropriate global scope to the marine environments represented. In Baltimore’s National Aquarium, as an example, “exhibits are environmental. The visitor becomes part of the environment - most notably in the tropical rain forest where a humid jungle atmosphere has been recreated” (Breen and Rigby 1988: 74). In Monterey, California, the aquarium incorporates the local-type rocks, surf and sand into the design. The whole museum, which the visitor can go through without ever getting wet, is designed to mirror the environment visible outside (Breen and Rigby 1987b: 74). In the New York Aquarium’s new “Discovery Cove,” according to a brochure, visitors can “walk through a salt marsh, stay dry inside crashing waves, and handle seastars, crabs, and urchins...[and]...See the giant kelp beds, magnificent coral formations, and hundreds of schooling fish.” Boston’s planned new aquarium will contain exhibits of local waterfront habitats that have not existed for generations, and even centuries, and through the use of underwater plexiglass tunnels, will create in visitors the illusion of being under and inside an ocean with no visible limits.
As the work of those who reside and labor near the water more and more draws urbanites from active use of the water, the water comes to be increasingly defined as natural wilderness, a frontier of civilization, and thereby an escape from ordinary urban pressures. Open space in general, and particularly that at the edge of expansive bodies of water, gains increasing meaning as outer limit of organized urban life. Even if the trend is to sharpen the boundaries between city and nature, however, it is important to recognize that this is done on the assumption that nature must be scientifically understood and interpreted, and
very carefully managed. This careful scientific management, in fact, is necessary to restore and assure its “natural” qualities.
(2) Heritage and historical preservation. The second major cultural theme in development of urban waterfronts is increased emphasis on their significance as historical settings and artifacts. The more waterfronts have lost importance as sites for industry and commerce, the more stress promoters have placed on preserving and celebrating maritime or river heritage as a way of creating a sense of character and tradition that distinguishes place. This paradoxical celebration of tradition in situations where its original cultural basis is rapidly eroding has been long noted in urban anthropology (e.g., Cohen 1969; Little 1973), although primarily in reference to ethnic symbols.
The images that urban populations construct and enact about their cities clearly display similar fluidity and paradox. There is also considerable selectivity in the traditions that are chosen to define urban identity, and in many cases the traditions are even recently “invented” ones with no real historical antecedents (Hobsbawm 1983; Cameron 1987). A prime example here is one of Boston’s major waterfront rituals, the 4th of July “Turnaround Cruise” of the USS Constitution (“Old Ironsides”) through Boston Harbor. Replete with pageantry, cannon salutes, and period naval costumes from the early 1800’s, the ceremony was actually initiated in 1976 for the American Revolution Bicentennial. Often, the images project a “sanitized” image of the maritime past, much like the sanitized-versions of western cowboy culture so important to the contemporary urban images and lifestyles in the western U.S.A. (Price 1972 and Walens 1973).
So-called “heritage marketing” is a key element in tourism in nearly every central city revitalization, whether on the waterfront or not (Judd and Collins 1979; Cameron 1989). According to an official of Greater Boston Convention and Visitors Bureau, in fact, “SHE - Seafood, history, and entertainment” are the key ingredients in all tourism marketing in Boston (Holton 1989: B3). Indeed, historic museums, walkways, buildings, ships and other restorations are central elements to waterfront developments everywhere. Historic and heritage festivals, such as Boston’s July 4th Harborfest, are also commonplace and provide opportunities for “living historical” costumes, commemorations, and reenactments of facets of past life in the port (Sieber 1990).
In Montreal, plans for Old Port, adjacent to the city’s restored Old Town, are dedicated to the theme of maritime heritage, and include a science and technology museum, a railroad museum, a historic interpretation center, and a relocated aquarium (Breen and Rigby 1987b: 65). In another example, New York State’s program of urban cultural parks, which aim to promote and interpret natural, historic, and cultural heritage, as a strategy in tourism and general economic development, has located 13 of its 14 installations on waterfronts (Breen and Rigby 1988: 72).
Typically, these emerging definitions of waterfront heritage privilege certain eras and cultures, and in seaports these are typically pre-industrial and elite
(Sieber 1990). For instance, historic ships like Boston’s Constitution, Baltimore's Constellation, San Francisco’s Balclutha — mostly older sailing ships — serve as central symbols of maritime heritage, that emphasize the mercantile, preindustrial era of these ports, rather than their more recent industrial, ethnic, and blue-collar dimensions. Sternwheelers, common restorations and tourist attractions in the Mississippi and Ohio River systems in such cities as Pittsburgh, Cincinnati, and New Orleans, carry a similar message.
In historical museums and festivals in Boston maritime heritage is typically defined as Yankee and pre-industrial. Ethnic and occupational heritages of blue collar working people are not represented, nor are steam vessels or factories. Out of over 100 events at the city’s 1988 Harborfest celebration, ostensibly a celebration of the city’s rich maritime history, only three events included a working-class or minority theme, and none of these - food and musical events - were related to maritime history or heritage. Representative examples of the festival’s explicitly “historical” events included: demonstrations of 18th century manual of arms routines by costumed militiamen; sail rigging demonstrations on the Beaver II (replica of the “Boston Tea Party” ship); a reenactment of an 18th century town meeting, complete with costumed performers interacting with the public; and a walking tour of “Paul Revere’s Boston.” While linking the post-industrial port city to its pre-industrial, mercantile past, this kind of symbolism also sharply differentiates the city from its more immediately receding industrial past. The industrial era, seen as ugly and polluting, is erased from view, and invisible in heritage representations. Although heritage symbolism is “traditional”, it paradoxically serves to mark discontinuity between the industrial and post-industrial eras (Sieber 1990).
(3) Tourism and recreation. Tourism and recreational development are everywhere central themes in all waterfront development, and in fact, in downtown redevelopment in general (Judd and Collins 1979). Once again, sharpening the contrast with the industrial era, waterfronts are defined as places of play, not work. Most waterfront developments deliberately cultivate a continuous “festival” atmosphere that defines the location as a place of release from the ordinary tensions of urban life and work. This is part of a general redefinition of central cities as “fun” places to be (Plotnicov 1986; Sieber 1989). In the waterfront context, this ambiance also highlights how much the kinds of labor discipline associated with the port’s industrial, working-class jobs no longer set the tone for the work taking place in this setting.
Plotnicov has written of the extensive cycle of public festivals in redeveloping Pittsburgh. He notes that the “most spectacular" of Pittsburgh’s festivals, in fact, is the Regatta at Point State Park at the confluence of the city’s three rivers, centering primarily on boating and other aquatic themes (Plotnicov 1986: 5). Other examples abound. In Toronto’s Harbourfront Development, covering 100 acres of the city's downtown waterfront, a converted warehouse known as York Quay Center, and the surrounding park, sponsor 4000 public
events a year, mostly arts performances, but also exhibits, contests, festivals, fairs, classes, and seminars. Events are programmed 16 hours a day, 7 days a week, and 365 days a year (Breen and Rigby 1987b: 61). In Long Beach, California, during the summer there are fireworks displays every night on the city’s waterfront (Breen and Rigby 1987b: 60). On Boston Harbor, major celebrations such as Harborpark Day, Harborfest, and the Antique & Classic Boat Show contribute to the ambiance, as do the continuous activities sponsored by the events department of Fanueil Hall Marketplace and by the Aquarium. These festivals, and other attractions like restaurants, performances, museums and historic sites, and specialty shops, attract not only out of town tourists, but day-trippers, usually suburbanites (Sieber 1997).
A large number of tourists to central cities are also business and convention travelers. In Boston business travelers and conventioneers are the core of the lucrative market for most downtown hotel and restaurant trade. The average tourist in Massachusetts, in fact, is college-educated white collar worker making over $40,000 per year (Massachusetts Office of Travel and Tourism 1988). As Plotnicov (1986, 1987) has indicated in his studies of Pittsburgh, tourists and resident professionals are also in a kind of symbiotic relationship to one another; they patronize the same set of services and lifestyle amenities. In particular, concentration of corporate headquarters and business services in the central business district permits the face-to-face encounters that are necessary to establishment of trust for completion of business transactions in the corporate world (Plotnicov 1987). Bars, restaurants, clubs, and hotels - as well as offices themselves - offer key sites for this kind of networking.
Lastly, the play-like elements of tourism and recreation, and the support they offer to business, should not obscure the fact that tourism and recreation are major growing sectors of the urban economy in their own right, especially in corporate cities. In Boston in the last 15 years, the health of this, one of the city’s major growth sectors, is attested to by: three new or expanded convention and exposition centers, two located directly on the waterfront; five new hotels, including three on the waterfront; and, at least six additional waterfront hotels in the planning stages. Ten percent of all city revenue derives from visitor-related activities (Judd and Collins 1979: 195).
Conclusions: Urban Waterfronts and Post-Industrial Directions in Urban Re-Development
Waterfront developments across North America offer a window into critical cultural themes in urban social change, especially in the emerging post-industrial city of the late 20th century. In these cities, much popular culture - especially those elements that offer representations and images of new urban realities - reflects the ascendancy of new metropolitan elites and their attempts to reshape urban infrastructure and culture in response to patterns of regional and global economic restructuring.
Popular cultural themes in waterfront revitalization offer sensible commentary on the changing urban scene. The chief messages are that the post-industrial city is sharply differentiated from its industrial predecessor; it is no longer chiefly a place for hard manual work, or the blue-collar working class, but instead the site for more self-directed professional and white collar organizational activity. The overall urban ambiance is one of play, choice, and festival, not work and compulsion. The port city’s recent industrial past is also rendered invisible in most urban preservation, heritage programming and marketing, and popular historical celebrations, which tend to focus as much as possible on pre-industrial themes, and on the city’s earlier role as service or administrative center. Finally, while the city’s relationship to nature continues to reflect an historic ambivalence toward urban artificiality (Sieber 1987), environmentalist themes display optimism that the legacy of industrial pollution can be remedied, and that the city - through careful management and restoration of its waterways - can establish for residents a more direct and intimate relationship with unspoiled nature, a situation not conceivable under an industrial regime.
It is true that these emerging cultural themes are most evident in the city’s redeveloped downtown sector, especially among urban newcomer and stranger groups, and appear to have less appeal overall to minorities and lower-income groups. Redeveloped waterfronts are notorious for unevenness in the distribution of their economic benefits to the urban population, greatly favoring the affluent (Tweedale 1988; Sieber 1989; Merainer 1990). Even if the emerging cultural themes are largely expressed in newly “invented” forms and have less than universal public appeal, however, they have genuine resonance for the urban situation of more bourgeois visitors and residents: urban professionals, suburban commuters, business travelers, and tourists. These themes, moreover, are increasingly guiding planning, land use, urban design, recreation, education, and public celebration: they are becoming hegemonic in waterfront redevelopment planning everywhere (Sieber 1989), and their broader public appeal thereby enhanced.
Recent work on indigenous cultural development suggests that today’s invented culture frequently becomes tomorrow’s traditional one, even coming to be appropriated by those who were its initial objects and whose historical and cultural realities it may have falsified (e.g., Hanson 1989; Jackson 1989). Invented traditions can also shape urban cultures as much as rural, indigenous ones. In North America, for example, John Price’s (1972) and Stanley Walens’ (1973) studies of Reno and Carson City, Nevada discuss the widespread adoption and emulation of an invented, sanitized version of U.S. western “cowboy” culture in urban design and lifestyle. In waterfront cities, moreover, the increasing hegemony of post-industrial themes - and their adoption as sensible by the public at large - is encouraged through their prominent dissemination in various contexts for public instruction, such as educational programs, park interpretation, public celebration, and museums (Sieber 1989).
The post-industrial trends in economy and culture described here have been evident in North American cities for a half century or more (Mollenkopf
1983), and it is clear that the current direction of urban development will only continue. It may be that the industrial city as we have known it, in the First and Second Worlds at least, has been a short-lived phase in urban evolution (Fainstein and Fainstein 1982). As more and more North American cities become “Manhattanized,” recent patterns of American urban social ecology also appear to be reversing themselves. Increasingly evident, in fact, is a growth pattern leading many North American cities in a more European-style direction, with the core the province of the elite, and the working class and poor residentially dispersed to outlying areas (Fainstein and Fainstein 1982). Although the literature is less extensive, waterfront revitalization, along with more general post-industrial transformations, have also been noted in Europe and Australasia, most often as part of general urban redevelopment (Hoyle et al 1988; Kendig 1986; Gale 1984). More studies are needed to explore the ways that planners and the public in varying national and local contexts respond differently, in redevelopment of their central cities and waterfronts, to the widespread pressures exerted by global economic restructuring.

The New Waterfront: principles, perceptions and practice in the UK and Canada
This paper is concerned with the phenomenon of waterfront redevelopment in port cities around the world, with special reference to the UK and Canada. Its objectives are to underline the principles involved, discuss some contrasted perceptions, and illustrate the phenomenon in practice through a range of examples. In recent decades the revitalization of urban waterfronts has spread from North America to Europe and Australasia, and to newly-industrializing and to less-developed countries. In the USA, Baltimore is one of the best-known examples from the older-established cityports of the east coast, as well as one of the most successful in terms of city-port integration. On the west coast, San Francisco displays other aspects of the same phenomenon as old commercial waterfronts around the urban core achieve a virtual resurrection in the context of 1990s tourism and water-related recreation. Canada, similarly, displays many examples of new waterfronts and the problems with which they are associated: Toronto, Vancouver and Montreal are among the more instructive cases.
In a European context, there are now many interesting and some controversial examples of the process - London, Genova, Marseille and Barcelona are well-known examples of port cities where not every aspect of recent waterfront revitalization has met with unadulterated acclaim. In the newly-industrializing countries of South-east Asia, Hong Kong presents one of the most spectacular examples of an ever-changing waterfront; and in the less-advanced developing countries, such as India, Cuba and Tanzania, a lot of effort is now being put into urban conservation including waterfront redevelopment, as for example in the old stone town of Zanzibar where some remarkable 19th-century buildings are being renovated.
Waterfront redevelopment is thus not just a local phenomenon, wherever it is observed or studied. It is not something that reflects only local circumstances in Portugal, or in Britain, or in Europe, or in the Mediterranean world, or in advanced countries. It is a global phenomenon now, and has become so quite

recently, during the past two or three decades. In examining waterfront redevelopment what we are looking at is a set of trends that are in the process of changing once more the face of port cities, and other cities on water, all around the world, not of course for the first time, but this time creating new and more attractive urban environments for the 21st century whilst simultaneously responding to late 20th-century changes in the technology of maritime transport and in concepts of urban design.
Cities on the sea
The waterfront is normally and essentially a water-orientated urban zone, and the water surface involved may be the sea, a river, a lake, or some artificial water body. Most commonly, however, waterfront revitalization is associated with the renewal of inner areas of port cities where the migration of the port function-to alternative sites has produced redundant urban space available for revitalization. In such locations it is useful to differentiate between the waterfront and the port-city interface. Figure I suggests a spatial and functional relationship between the inner city, port-owned land, and the waterfront, with a two-way flow of goods, people and influences between port and city. These relationships vary with location, of course, and also in terms of the perspectives involved, which might be to do with finance, or land-use planning, or morphology. The essential point is that the port-city interface is a dynamic zone in transition. The waterfront is often also a dynamic zone in transition. But the two zones are not identical (although they may overlap) in form or in function. The waterfront and its redevelopment may be subsumed within the controversial port-city interface zone of conflict and occasional collaboration.
The two final stages of the port-city evolution model (Fig. 2) evoke the renewed collaboration between port and city that occurs as waterfront zones are revitalized. These phases of waterfront redevelopment and enhanced port-city proximity are today associated with urban renewal programmes in innumerable cities around the world. Waterfront redevelopment has the effect of removing barriers between a city and the sea, bringing people back to the waterfront once again - as individuals, groups, organizations, observers and participants in sporting events, customers, residents, and people who just enjoy being near or on the water.
Rationale: causes and consequences
The original rationale that underpins the waterfront redevelopment phenomenon is basically fairly clear, although complex in the ways it is worked out in practice, in actual cases. As maritime technology advanced, and required ever larger land and water areas to discharge the port function, that port function
has been forced to migrate towards deeper water and more extensive land sites. For ports located on rivers and estuaries, this usually (although not invariably) means downstream migration, and for many such ports this is an acceleration of that downstream movement, not an innovation.
In urban terms the result is a vacuum, an abandoned doorstep, a problematic planning zone often in or very close to the traditional heart of a port city, a zone of dereliction and decay where once all was bustle and interchange and activity. What to do about this problem zone becomes a major planning issue, but is also soon perceived as an opportunity - to make money, to replan and redevelop, and to bring the city back to the waterfront once more, in a new and updated context. The challenge presented by this process is quite considerable, because it involves major adjustments for both ports and cities. On the one hand there are new locational requirements for ports, and on the other the redesigning of substantial areas of cities. Urban renewal involves, of course, not just physical infrastructures but also communities. The impact of revitalization on society goes hand in hand with the impact on the environment. Both are almost invariably controversial.
We should remember, however, that this standard process of urban waterfront redevelopment in port cities, rooted in maritime technology as the causal factor, is not the whole and entire explanation of the waterfront redevelopment phenomenon as we know it today. The attractiveness of the idea of waterfront redevelopment is such that it has become an element in the late 20th-century revival of settlements of all kinds, not just port cities, and indeed has extended to rural waterfront locations as well, along riverbanks, in wetlands, and in water-based conservation areas. So although in many contexts the discussion of waterfront redevelopment concerns ports and port cities, we need to be aware that for many people the origins of waterfront redevelopment lie for all practical purposes in the field of urban planning, design and renewal, not in the sphere of changing maritime technology and its effects.
Geographical spread
The geographical diffusion of the phenomenon is also interesting because it has taken place in several dimensions: around the globe; from larger to smaller urban places; and, in a sense, down the development ladder from the more advanced towards the less-developed countries. One could argue, of course, that waterfront redevelopment is a basic part of the life of any active, growing port city at any time in its development. Traditionally, a port city’s waterfront has been its commercial front door, and its relative efficiency, attractiveness and competitiveness have long underpinned its trading fortunes.
But waterfront revitalization in the more restricted sense in which we use the term today really started in North America in the 1960s, notably in Boston, Baltimore and San Francisco, and spread to European port cities (most notably
to London) in the 1970s and 1980s and also to Australia where Sydney is an interesting case to look at. In the 1990s it has become important in the newly-industrializing countries and the developing countries too. Almost every city with a waterfront is now doing something about revitalizing it. Again, that does not just mean port cities, of course, but all kinds of other cities on lakes, rivers, canals and other artificial water bodies of all sorts. People like to be near the water - not necessarily in it or even on it - to visit, to have a meal, to buy an apartment, to go for a sail, to watch other people. Waterfronts attract people, and have ways of extracting their money from them.
Today an increasing number of locations outside the traditional Euro-American and Australasian advanced country group are actively becoming involved in the waterfront revitalization movement. Singapore has completed a clean-up of its formerly characterful old harbour; Havana (Cuba) is planning to spend a lot of money on renovating some still characterful old waterfront buildings before they collapse. In South Africa, Cape Town is firmly on this bandwaggon with the redevelopment of the Victoria and Alfred waterfront - the first major development of this sort on the African continent. In East Africa, substantial efforts are being made to save and revitalize waterfront buildings in Mombasa, Lamu, Dar es Salaam and Zanzibar in the context of urban conservation.
Retreat, redundancy and revitalization
Against this background the model of waterfront retreat, redundancy and revitalization (Fig. 3) is another way of summarizing the processes going on in port cities today. This diagram, in which time advances from the top towards the bottom, conceptualizes the links between the retreat from the traditional waterfront, the problem of redundant space, and the revitalization process. An initial situation originating in technological change and de-industrialization leads to the retreat of port users and port authorities, and to a downward transition in the maritime quarters of port cities. These negative factors yield redundant space, initially (t/) in the urban core, but eventually (t2) in other related areas beyond, possibly including some originally greenfield sites for industries (such as oil refining) that are no longer needed and close down. Retreat then produces a process involving problem perception and analysis, and some sites are favoured and others not, when it comes to planning for redevelopment - this is what the diagram calls a ‘revitalization selection filter’.
Then a more positive situation sets in, dominated by integrated and often controversial redevelopment. There is an increasing perception of resource opportunity. All kinds of organizations become involved - public authorities, port authorities, commercial interests. As ideas about redevelopment are refined, the arrow representing strategy formulation and evolution becomes quite wide, indicating that all sorts of ideas and proposals are discussed - but then the arrow becomes more sharply targeted as the planning process eventually reaches a
practical and workable solution. Emulation of success elsewhere is often a factor. On the ground, outcomes reflect the balance between commercial interests and social goals, and achieving that balance is often a source of conflict. Revitalization sometimes pays a lot of attention to commercial opportunities but not very much to the social needs of communities - the people who already live in the areas where all this change is happening. So the outcome continuum, in reality, is weighted towards the commercial end of the spectrum both initially (r/) and even more so later, as the redevelopment becomes more consolidated, and predominance of commercial interests is enhanced (r2).
The study of waterfront revitalilization
There is now an extensive literature on the subject of waterfront revitalization in geography, planning and related disciplines. International conferences held at Southampton in 1979 and 1987 yielded two edited books: Hoyle and Pinder (1981), Cityport industrialization and regional development, and Hoyle, Pinder and Husain (1988), Revitalizing the waterfront: international dimensions of dockland redevelopment. The 1987 conference was the first academic meeting of its kind to consider waterfront redevelopment trends on a global basis, as opposed to reporting and reviewing individual cases. The introductory chapter in the 1988 book, entitled ‘Development dynamics at the port-city interface’, reviewed geographical studies of the port-city interface and highlighted work by recognised contributors to the literature such as Bird, Hayuth and Norcliffe.
Important contributions have been made by several other centres where these issues are discussed, analysed and publicised. For example, at the Waterfront Center in Washington, D.C., the co-directors, Ann Breen and Dick Rigby, organize annual conferences essentially for practicioners - designers, developers, architects, planners etc - rather than students of ports and urban change and of the revitalization processes. Breen and Rigby have produced two substantial volumes. The first, called Waterfronts: cities reclaim their edge appeared in 1994 and is a useful compendium of case studies. For a review of its place in the literature see Pinder (1994). The second, entitled The new waterfront: a worldwide urban success story, was published in 1996 and has been reviewed by Hoyle (1997).
Another centre of activity in this field is Venice, Italy, where the Centro Internazionale Citta d’Acqua (International Centre Cities on Water), under the guidance of its director, Dr Rinio Bruttomesso, has organized several international conferences of relevance to cities on water - for example, on sea-level change, transport, waterfronts, and the conservation of older industrial buildings. The Venice waterfronts conference produced a useful book entitled Waterfronts: a new frontier for cities on water (Bruttomesso, 1993) which contains numerous useful contributions and case studies, including an overview of the field by Professor Peter Hall (Hall, 1993).
Recent contributions to the field include four significant items published in 1996. Two books: Brian Hudson’s Cities on the shore: the urban littoral frontier - a broad and essentially urban perspective on the scene (Hudson, 1996); and Patrick Malone’s edited volume City, capital and water which is more political and architectural in approach (Malone, 1996). Papers by Norcliffe et al. (1996) and by Gordon (1996) respectively discuss ‘The emergence of postmodernism on the urban waterfront’ and ‘Planning, design and managing change in urban waterfront redevelopment’. Both are important contributions to the growing literature.
The UK experience
In the UK a lot of interest has been shown in waterfront redevelopment from the 1970s onwards, as the fashion for new waterfronts has spread around the world. Here the phenomenon is basically related to a long-standing inner city crisis, especially in some of the older, larger cities such as Liverpool. National and local authorities in the UK were initially rather slow to take up opportunities for waterfront revitalization, in the 1970s and early 1980s, but perhaps in the long run that was no bad thing. Several major British cityports, and many smaller ones too, have by now achieved a remarkable transformation of some of their abandoned docklands, dilapidated warehouses, derelict waterfronts and substandard housing close to city centres. Liverpool is a good example, where the redevelopment of the Albert Dock - to include a new Tate Gallery for the North as well as a wide range of other cultural and leisure elements - is widely regarded as successful. An interesting comparison has been made between Liverpool and the Mediterranean port city of Alexandria in terms of their experience of waterfront renewal (Ewais, 1988). Another such comparison might be made between Liverpool and the inland city of Birmingham, where cultural revival and physical renewal have also included an element of waterfront revitalization. Birmingham is featured in the second (1996) Breen and Rigby book. However, nothing else in Britain quite compares with the dramatic changes that have taken place in London’s Docklands where vast sums have been spent on creating new urban landscapes and waterscapes. The way in which this has been done has been much criticised as a financial, social and planning disaster, and the Canary Wharf tower initially came to symbolise, for some, political ineptitude. More recently, however, the transformation of the London Docklands has been recognised as an eventual triumph and as a symbol of a strong and powerful economy in a European and a global context. Beyond these major cases, in the rest of the country it seems nowadays that, as in North America, every city that has a waterfront - on the sea, or on a lake or river - is doing something to revitalise it, or at least to smarten it up a bit. Many other port cities around the UK have joined this trend - Cardiff, Bristol, Edinburgh, Glasgow, Gloucester, Hull, Manchester, Swansea, and Portsmouth are among well-known examples.
Southampton
The ancient port city of Southampton on the south coast of England is experiencing some exciting changes in this context (Fig. 4). In the oldest part of the Eastern Docks, Southampton started in the mid-1980s to join the waterfront revitalization trend, triggered by the concentration of cross-Channel ferry services at Portsmouth in 1984. The port of Southampton no longer needed a substantial area in the north-east corner of this artificial peninsula, and in a context created by 19th-century port expansion we now have, ten years on, an Ocean Village, a redeveloped zone of shops, houses, cinemas, restaurants, commercial premises, museums, apartments and of course a marina. The development policy has been for mixed land and water use, for work and play, for residents and visitors, and the basic idea is to bring the city back to its waterfront. The University of Southampton has established the new Southampton Oceanography Centre as a world-class centre for deep-sea research. In practice it remains to be seen whether these diverse elements will in practice successfully blend together. They appear to be beginning to do so, although it has taken a while. Southampton has not been wholly spared by the adverse social reactions that surfaced in London’s Docklands as friction grew between established communities and comers-in, the former often relatively poor and the latter intent on buying expensive waterfront properties with personalised moorings for the yacht and private parking for expensive motor cars.
Like many other individual case studies, Southampton underlines many of the principles of waterfront revitalization. Changes in maritime technology, and the port-selection process by ship operators, created a vacuum on Southampton’s waterfront, in a city that already had a vacuum between the downtown commercial core and the sea, the core having moved northwards following German bombardment in the Second World War. Between the mid-1980s when these opportunities arose, and the mid-1990s, new landscapes and waterscapes have been created and become widely known internationally - through television coverage of the BT Global Challenge and other round-the-world yacht races which use Ocean Village as a starting or finishing point.
Canada: experience and analysis
Canada is also a country where much exciting waterfront revitalization has taken place, and this has generated a good deal of interesting literature in geography and planning, as well as in related politico-economic fields. Canada’s major coastal settlements usually originated as ports, but many inland cities (such as Kingston, Ontario) were also at one time highly dependent upon water transport. Also - as Toronto illustrates better than any other Canadian port city - in recent decades there has been a marked divergence between port functions and urban functions.
Some Canadian port cities experiencing waterfront change are very large places - such as Vancouver (British Columbia) - of major importance as ports and as cities. On a complex site, Vancouver is Canada’s largest port by far, and urban waterfront redevelopment has taken place in specific locations on False Creek - where the Granville Island leisure complex has replaced a derelict industrial site - and on Burrard Inlet where the architecturally striking Pacific Place is a major recreational complex, conference centre and cruise terminal alongside the container berths further east along the waterfront. Montreal (Quebec), with its linear port facilities along the St Lawrence, has made relatively slow progress in redeveloping its urban waterfront, although it now boasts one of the world’s best museums on the site of the earliest Indian and European settlements on Montreal island. Halifax (Nova Scotia) has been more successful in some ways, partly because of the geographical proximity of the downtown core and the redeveloping waterfront. Renovated historic properties, once nearly demolished, are now an integral part of the city’s life and character, attracting many tourists as well as local people to the waterfront. Victoria (British Columbia) has also proved controversial, with arguments polarising around whether the waterfront should be largely given over to tourism and residential land use - largely through the process known as condo-isation1, much resented locally by some - or whether a working harbour should at all costs be maintained. Overall, there is remarkable diversity, and Canada is a wonderful laboratory for studying situations, problems and redevelopment techniques in this field.
Toronto
Toronto is perhaps the most interesting Canadian case study in this context, and in many ways Canada’s most complex and controversial waterfront. In academic terms, Toronto is also the original home of waterfront redevelopment studies in Canada, on the basis of long-established research traditions in transportation at the University of Toronto, in the downtown area, and at York University in the northern suburbs.
Toronto is Canada’s largest city. It is the economic focus of Ontario, of eastern Canada and in some ways of the country as a whole. As a city Toronto has spread far and wide to the north, west and east from its original site on the north shore of Lake Ontario. Yet as a port Toronto is of relatively minor significance today. Its traffic declined sharply in the 1970s and 1980s, while Montreal and Vancouver, in contrast, successfully maintained and enhanced their positions as the pre-eminent seaport gateways to eastern and western Canada respectively. The contrast between a burgeoning city and a moribund port is today all too plain, and Toronto is an excellent example of a city that has found itself very much in the right location for some purposes, but not for others, as time has gone by - a not uncommon experience of cities past and present. Early French and British trading activity led to the selection of Toronto Bay as the
site of the new capital of Upper Canada in 1791, named York shortly thereafter. Toronto enjoyed over a century of prosperous expansion. The industrializing city of the 19th century - with canals, railways and a port authority - grew rapidly and had a series of finger piers projecting from the central lakeshore; but early in the 20th century these were infilled and replaced by a new port-industrial zone to the east, towards Ashbridge’s Bay; the railway companies gradually developed water-encroaching sites for transport and industrial uses, pushing the city’s water frontier further and further south into the lake.
In 1912, the newly-established Toronto Harbour Commissioners - the port authority - published a grandiose scheme for industrial and port development -a comprehensive Waterfront Development Plan which “represented a large-scale refashioning of the waterfront along its entire length for port, industrial, transportation and recreational purposes. A key part of the scheme was the systematic lake-filling along the water’s edge. The net effect... was the creation of a new waterfront, located south of the previous one, much of which had been taken over by the railways by the end of the nineteenth century’’ (Desfor et al., 1988, 97). This was clearly a major re-fashioning of the Toronto waterfront at an early date, and its essential effect was to shift port and industrial activities eastwards, off centre-stage and further along the Iakeshore, while inevitably retaining the rail-dominated transport axis along the waterfront including that part of it between the downtown and the lake.
The combination of the lakeshore railway axis and rapidly developing industrial zone to the east re-emphasised an emerging barrier between Lake Ontario and the growing city. There is a well-known account of this problem close to its inception in the Letters from America written by the English poet Rupert Brooke during his journey across Canada in 1913:
“Toronto ... (is) a brisk city of getting on for half a million inhabitants, the largest British city in Canada ... It is situated on the shores of a lovely lake; but you never see that, because the railways have occupied the entire lake front. So if, at evening, you try to find your way to the edge of the water, you are checked by a region of smoke, sheds, trucks, wharves, storehouses, depots, railway lines, signals and locomotives and trains that wander up and down and across streets, pushing their way through the pedestrians, and tolling, as they go, in the American fashion, an immense melancholy bell” (Brooke, 1916; repr. 1984, pp. 80-81).
Well might the bell toll! The story of Toronto’s waterfront change has continued full of difficulties and disagreements from then until now. The features Brooke described were perpetuated until the post-1946 period when suburban growth and the threat of inner-city decline focussed renewed attention on the waterfront and its planning needs.
In the 1950s and 1960s people began to realise that Toronto was in the wrong place to prosper as a major port - in relation to the St Lawrence Seaway, to rail competition, to the advantages of Montreal and to Toronto’s own water site. So Toronto by the mid-1960s had a waterfront ripe for redevelopment. The way in which that redevelopment has taken place is an object lesson for urban geographers, planners, and politicians. In the 1960s the railways did not want to give up their land, even when they did not really need it anymore and when it had come to form a barrier between the urban area and the water. The Harbour Commissioners, for their part, faced serious financial difficulties due to declining port activity (accelerated after the opening of the St Lawrence Seaway in 1959, which effectively meant that a lot of traffic by-passed Toronto rather than using the port as a transhipment point). This meant that the THC saw the value of their lands and investments seriously reduced .
The Federal Government set up a public development agency in 1972 called Harbourfront, designed to promote the redevelopment of some of those railway lands along the lake shore for residential and recreational purposes rather than for industry or transport. This policy led, through the 1970s and 1980s, to the construction of offices, hotels and apartment blocks (some converted from old warehouses) along the redeveloping waterfront. This had the effect of creating a concrete curtain between the city and the lake, with relatively little green or other open space between. The CN tower and the adjacent 55,000-seater Skydome stadium (1989) provide a focal point.
A characteristic Canadian dimension of this sort of problem is political interaction between a wide range of major players on the scene - in this case the Harbour Commissioners (the original port authority), the Harbourfront Corporation (the federal development agency), the City Council, the railway companies (Canadian National and Canadian Pacific) and the Ontario provincial and Ottawa federal govermhents - all this, together with actual and would-be developers putting their schemes into the melting pot, produced an atmosphere of increased public controversy over the pattern and character of the emerging, redeveloping waterfront. While the rising ‘concrete curtain’ was a common target of opposition, some thought that ‘too much green’ might also be undesirable. In 1988 the Federal Government set up a Royal Commission to study the future of the Toronto waterfront, in effect declaring a moratorium on further development until such time as a broadly agreed strategy for the waterfront could be worked out. The final report of the Commission, published in 1992, provides a basis for a more balanced plan and was received with keen interest.
The Toronto example does not quite fit established models of waterfront redevelopment which indicate the migration of expanding port facilities from the urban core to larger-scale bluecoast sites, some degree of industrial relocation and restructuring, competition for land and water sites close to the inner city core, and conflict at the port/city interface between the actors involved. If we compare this with the Toronto experience we see that some of these things fit in quite well but the picture is in reality more complex. In Toronto the recent
impetus for inner-urban waterside renewal has arisen not from a growr/i-propelled migration of port activities to alternative sites, but from port decline, urban economic restructuring, and the re-use of railway lands. Toronto-style waterfront re-development thus initially involved water-encroaching sites, migration eastwards and artificial harbour creation. Recent revitalization has involved lands occupied by (or created for) port-related industries and transport facilities (especially lakeshore railways) rather than land and water space recently vacated by port functions. So it can be argued that because of the migration and decline of port activity, the port function does not lie directly at the root of modern urban waterfront redevelopment in Toronto to the same degree, or in quite the same way, as in some other port cities undergoing this sort of change.
This discrepancy illustrates an interesting divergence between European and Canadian writers on waterfront redevelopment. From a European perspective, based on the experience of many port cities sited on estuaries and gradually developing downstream, urban waterfront redevelopment today is closely associated with the migration of the port function which is itself a result of changes in maritime technology. The root cause of waterfront change and the emergence of the new waterfront is thus to do with shipping and with the sea. In the middle of continental Canada people do not necessarily see things that way. When asked what is the ultimate, basic, root cause of waterfront redevelopment in Canadian port cities today, many people would point to urban socio-economic change and restructuring, rather than to anything to do with maritime technology. It is an interesting question, and the answer depends on how far back one chooses to go in seeking the real reasons why things happen.
Toronto is an interesting and perhaps an aberrant case, but one that also reflects a common Canadian problem and experience involving railway-dominated industrial waterfronts that are a basic part of Canadian economic history but which no longer fit with late 20th-century ideas of urban design. Toronto has experienced not one but several waves of waterfront redevelopment this century - the 1912 Harbour Commissioners, the 1970s Harbourfront initiative, the 1990s Royal Commission - so now is not the first time that this waterfront has been identified as a planning problem. Interestingly, there is a close comparison with Southampton on the point that the controversial redeveloping zone between the city and the sea is artificial land, progressively reclaimed by a water-encroaching city stimulated by industrial, port and railway activities in various combinations.
There is a political complexity and a sensitivity about the Toronto case that takes some time to appreciate (Desfor et al., 1989; Goldrick and Merrens, 1996). The transformation process involves a major city and a minor port; four levels of government (federal, provincial, metropolitan and city) which from time to time change their political colour; plus the landowning railway companies, the landowning port authority, and the property developers too. It was onto that complex stage that the Royal Commission on the Future of the Toronto Waterfront stepped out in 1988, providing a new window of opportunity to
rethink the issues involved, and to allow as many people as possible some say in answering the question ‘What kind of a waterfront do we want for the 21st century?’ The answers provided in the 1992 Final Report are leading, and in part have already led, to greatly enhanced environmental awareness along the whole of the urban waterfront from the far western suburbs to the deindustrializing eastern zones; to a greater understanding of the processes involved; and to a more realistic accommodation between the various authorities and the people of this complex multicultural city (Greenberg, 1996). Specific outcomes have included a Waterfront Regeneration Trust - which acts basically as an advisory and monotoring body - and a Waterfront Resource Centre - which is a very substantial source of information, documentation, photographic archives for all who are interested in the problem in general or in specific stretches of the waterfront. Part of the port zone is being redeveloped by commercial organizations (rather in the manner of Southampton’s Eastern Docks, in fact), with housing and shopping and other uses being found for a reviving segment of the declining and largely redundant port area. Developers and community representatives have come together to discuss this project, and this seems a hopeful sign. So a lot of progress has been made, but the concrete curtain is still there, and the Gardiner Expressway is still there, and Toronto is still by no means reunited with the lakeshore which gave it birth. As Rupert Brooke said, “Such is Toronto ... It is impossible to give it anything but commendation ... It is all right... The only depressing thing is that it will always be what it is, only larger ...” (Brooke, 1916, pp. 80, 83-4). One might ask what Rupert Brooke would say about Toronto and its still problematic waterfront if he could see it again today. It is, at least, a provocative question.
Conclusions
Just as we can recognise a common sequence of stages and a common set of factors underlying cityport growth and change in general, and that this sequence and these factors underpin both similarities and the distinctiveness of each location, we can also see that this principle applies specifically and effectively to waterfront redevelopment. But is waterfront redevelopment really a worldwide urban success story, as the Breen and Rigby claim? I would question that statement. The process may be happening in many countries all around the world, but it is not happening everywhere, and it certainly is not universal. It is not wholly or even primarily urban, in origin. And it certainly isn’t an undiluted success.
What is much more clear, however, is that port/city interface is sensitive and controversial, and needs careful, appropriate planning solutions. But, as Singapore illustrates, these are not always available or applied with sufficient finesse. There has been a good deal of criticism about the way in which the cleaning-up operation around the old harbour, the removal of traditional Chinese
sailing vessels, the sanitization of the whole area, has detracted from its character and interest both for visitors and local people. The revitalization process can perhaps be overdone. The basic difficulty involved in waterfront redevelopment schemes is the reconciliation of the many inter-related influences, objectives and interests involved, as Toronto clearly shows. The search for a common, shared vision may be present, but it is rarely totally successful. How, in any case, is success to be judged? Like many other things in geography, transport and urban planning, this topic brings together an understanding of global processes and an appreciation of the distinctiveness of individual locations and environments. ‘Success’ is not simply a matter of financial investment, not just a matter of creating a modern waterside playground, but it involves a more deep-rooted reunion between cities and the sea. The popular success of many new waterfronts reflects the inherent magic of water, drawing people together, and it is a tangible sign of the continuing vitality of cities and of well-established global trends that have subtantial geographical implications and expressions.
